title: Report supports Indon, HK free trade deals
text:
Australia's free trade deals with Indonesia and Hong Kong have taken a major step forward after a bipartisan parliamentary committee gave them the green light.

The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties has released reports on both deals, recommending action on a binding treaty "as soon as possible".

Trade Minister Simon Birmingham said Labor should support the trade agreement legislation, which could be introduced to parliament as soon as next week.

"I urge my parliamentary colleagues to help deliver the benefits of these trade agreements by passing the enabling legislation as soon as possible," he said on Wednesday.

Unions have pushed back strongly against the agreements because they include investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) clauses, which allow foreign companies to sue the government.

ACTU president Michele O'Neil called on Labor, Greens and crossbench senators to oppose the agreements.

"Trade agreements should improve the lives of working people, not put their interests second to multinationals," she said.

She warned the Indonesian agreement would increase temporary work visas, without testing whether Australian workers could do the job.

"To support the deal with Hong Kong in the midst of violent repression of democratic protests is unacceptable," Ms O'Neil said.

Labor MPs on the committee wanted labour market testing for any future agreement with Indonesia on contractors to be included but the recommendation was rejected.

Committee chair and Liberal MP Dave Sharma said it was important for Australia to stand up for free trade at a time of rising protectionism.

"The treaty actions considered in this report represent substantial gains for Australian industry, agriculture and business and therefore for the Australian economy," he wrote.

Labor's trade spokeswoman Madeline King said while the party didn't support ISDS provisions in trade agreements, the report noted the Indonesian safeguards were equivalent to be the best Australia had agreed to.

"Labor will continue to push for the expertise of industry, unions and community groups in the course of trade negotiations," she said.

"However, we acknowledge that the report concludes that these agreements are ultimately in Australia's national interest."

The Greens issued a dissenting report which recommended not ratifying the trade deals.
